Comment: This take doesn't make any sense when we have been living through the worst overdose crisis in the country's history for the last decade, fueled by a toxic street supply of drugs containing fentanyl, xylazine, and other adulterants. It is riskier to do drugs now than it was 30 years ago. Over the last two years we have just started to see this trend reversed, and the saturation of naloxone is perhaps the biggest reason for that. And the program cited in the article specifically funds training for first responders in states like Missouri that have been hit hardest by the overdose crisis, plus resources to help people get into treatment and recovery.

Comment: Has nothing to do with needle exchange though, these are programs which train first responders on how to use and administer naloxone, and funds leave behind kits which give people information about treatment and recovery options. From the article:  >Matthew Cushman, a fire department paramedic in Raytown, Mo., said that through the naloxone grant program, he had trained thousands of police officers, firefighters and emergency medical responders throughout Kansas City and western rural areas. The program provides trainees with pouches of naloxone to administer in the field plus “leave behind” kits with information about detox and treatment clinics.

Comment: Mike Pence had those same doubts, and his late action on approving a needle exchange resulted in [200+ new HIV cases in one year alone](https://www.nbcnews.com/politics/white-house/pence-s-handling-2015-hiv-outbreak-gets-new-scrutiny-n1144786), in an area that was typically seeing 5 cases a year.
